definition: In this task, you're given a news article. Your job is to identify the umbrella topic of the article and write a set of 5 discussion questions pertaining the umbrella topic for opinion writing. You are not only provide the questions, in numbered bullet point form. You are not to provide anything aside from the questions in numbered bullet point form. You may assume that the writer has background experience on the umbrella topic. Good questions are expected to critically question the umbrella topic with reference to the article. Do not ask questions that can be answered correctly without understanding the paragraph. Each of your questions must be unique from the rest.
context: Frederick Lim
I never got to know my father well. He died suddenly when I was nine. He was only 44.

Although I didn’t have much time with him, I have fond memories of my boyhood days. And on Father’s Day every year, I look at his photograph, say a little prayer for him, and thank him for all that he gave me during our brief time together.

I grew up in Klang, a city in Selangor in Malaysia, where my father worked as a civil servant. After his death, my mother, older brother and I moved to Singapore where my uncle gave us a place to live. We lived modestly, with my father’s government pension and financial help from my uncle. There was no money for extras.

It was the absence of my father that marked my days back then. I missed how he doted on my brother and me, how he came home with presents and took us out to the movies. Most of all, I missed how he answered all our endless questions, which came easy for him as he had encyclopaedic knowledge.
What I remember most are the lessons he taught me that have guided me throughout my growing-up years and shaped my personality.
As a young boy, I took my father’s words as gospel truth and the advice he gave as gold, holding them close to my heart.
The biggest lesson has to be the “272-steps lesson”.

When I was around six years old, our family visited the Batu Caves Hindu temple near Kuala Lumpur. The mouth of Batu Caves was at the top of numerous and steep steps. When my father said there were 272 steps, I told him I would not make it all the way to the top.

His reply gave me the motivation to go for it: Getting to the top was just a matter of taking 16 steps to reach a landing, then another 16 steps to get to the next one, and if I kept going from one landing to another, I would reach the caves.
And so we climbed – my father holding my hand and both of us counting the steps out loud until we reached the caves.
The lesson learnt: Don’t be daunted by a big problem, as it can be tackled by breaking it down into smaller, more manageable parts.

I applied this lesson throughout my life – breaking a task into smaller steps, stages and sequences to eventually get it done. This approach to problem-solving has stood me in good stead in my personal and professional life.

When I was 45, I made a mid-career switch from stockbroking to journalism, joining CNA as a business reporter. As I knew little about TV production, I applied what my father taught me – do things in steps, stages and sequences. In time, with training and learning on the job, I became a senior editor of the station’s business programme.

Another lesson I learnt from my father was foundation-building. I remember as a child stacking building blocks, putting a square or round piece on top of another to see how high I could build the tower before the whole structure came crashing down.

My first few attempts collapsed in double-quick time. After seeing my failed attempts, my father showed me how I needed to build a strong foundation in order to get taller towers. I should not rush it, and take care to align the pieces to get a more stable structure.
I followed his advice, and my towers stood tall and did not collapse.

Building strong foundations became an integral part of everything I did in life. I was always well prepared before an examination, I trained hard before running a marathon, and I researched extensively before covering a news event.

My father also made sure he built a strong foundation in the education of his two sons. When we turned three, he introduced us to the alphabet, taught us numbers and read books to us to build up our vocabulary. He made us do simple sums and memorise the multiplication table.

On our family trips to other towns in Malaysia, my father would make us solve mental maths problems. To keep us occupied during the long drives, he asked us to work out how long it would take to get to the destination based on the speed of the car and the distance left to go.
There were also memory games, such as naming the capital cities of countries and the dates of historical events.

We went to the library regularly to borrow books, and he bought junior encyclopaedias to help us improve our general knowledge. He helped us with homework and reminded us to always go beyond what we learnt in school.
I grew up loving books and studied English literature in school. I developed a passion for writing and published two novels.

My father was a kind-hearted and generous man. He gave to charities readily and lent money to his cash-strapped colleagues. Our barber, who needed money for his family in India, borrowed from my father, who never asked for the loan to be repaid.
He talked to us about faith, and most importantly, showed us through his actions the importance of living life with honesty and integrity.

He told me never to take what was not mine at times when I found things. When I was a Scout in school, he reminded me during Job Week that I should do my best, as I was getting paid for the work. He told me he always gave his all, for the organisations he worked in and the people he worked with.

Of course, my father had his weaknesses. He loved food too much, often overate and rarely exercised. As he was only in his 40s when he died from typhoid fever, I have always wondered if he could have recovered from the bacterial infection if he had taken better care of his health.

My father could also be indecisive and lacked composure. I remember an incident when a beehive at the back of our house fell to the ground, and my father ran for cover from the swarm of bees. My mother’s quick thinking in setting the hive on fire saved the day.

Despite his shortcomings and his brief time with us, he had a lasting impact on our lives. I would like to think that he had a hand in the success story of my brother, who rose through the ranks to become a rear-admiral in the Singapore Navy and was Chief of Navy before he retired.

Although I do not have children of my own, I do have advice for all the fathers out there – teach your children well, as what you say will leave an indelible impression and stay with them for the rest of their lives. Just like how my father’s words and wise counsel have guided me through mine.
So this Father’s Day, I will gaze upon the photo of my dad, and thank him for making me who I am today.
question: 1. What was the biggest lesson your father taught you that has guided you throughout your growing-up years and shaped your personality?
answer: One of the biggest lessons my father taught me is the importance of hard work and perseverance. Growing up, I remember him always emphasizing the value of putting in effort and never giving up, regardless of the challenges that come our way. This lesson has stayed with me throughout my life and has become a fundamental part of my personality.

Firstly, I learned that success is not achieved overnight, but rather through consistent effort and dedication. My father has always been a hard-working man, and his example has inspired me to work hard and strive for excellence in all that I do. This lesson has taught me the value of patience, persistence, and resilience, and has helped me to overcome obstacles and setbacks along the way.

Secondly, I learned that failure is a natural part of the learning process. My father has never been afraid to take risks and try new things, and he has always encouraged me to do the same. However, he has also taught me that failure is not the end, but rather an opportunity to learn and grow from our mistakes. This has helped me to develop a growth mindset and to embrace challenges as opportunities for personal development.

Finally, I learned that success is not just about what you achieve, but also about how you achieve it. My father has always emphasized the importance of integrity, honesty, and ethics in all that we do. He has taught me that success is not just about achieving our goals, but also about how we treat others and how we contribute to the greater good. This has helped me to develop a strong sense of purpose and to make decisions that align with my values and principles.

Overall, the lesson of hard work and perseverance that my father taught me has had a profound impact on my life. It has shaped my personality, my values, and my approach to life, and has helped me to overcome challenges and achieve my goals. I am grateful for his guidance and for the example he has set for me, and I strive to pass on this valuable lesson to others.
summarised_answer: 1. The importance of hard work and perseverance is a fundamental lesson taught by parents.
2. Success is achieved through consistent effort and dedication, and failure is an opportunity to learn and grow.
3. Success is not just about achieving goals but also about how we treat others and contribute to the greater good.
4. The lesson of hard work and perseverance has had a profound impact on the life of the author.
summarised_input: 1. Frederick Lim never got to know his father well as he died suddenly when he was only 9 years old.
2. The essay is about the lessons that Frederick Lim's father taught him and how these lessons have shaped his personality.
3. The essay is not about the author's personal experiences.
4. The essay is not about the author's opinions on any particular topic.
5. The essay is not about any current events or news.

question: 2. How did your father's absence during your childhood impact your days back then?
answer: Growing up without a father figure in the household can have a significant impact on a child's development. For me, my father's absence during my childhood had a profound impact on my days back then.

Firstly, it made me feel lonely and isolated at times. I missed having a father to talk to and confide in, someone to provide guidance and support. This loneliness often made me feel like I was the only one going through difficult times, and it made me more vulnerable to emotional pain.

Secondly, it made me more independent and self-reliant. With my father absent, I had to learn to take care of myself and my siblings more. I had to figure out how to do things on my own, like doing laundry, cooking, and even taking care of my younger siblings. This made me more responsible and independent, and it taught me valuable life skills that I still use today.

Lastly, it made me more resilient and adaptable. Growing up without a father figure, I had to learn how to navigate difficult situations and challenges on my own. This taught me how to be more resilient and adaptable, and it made me more confident in my ability to handle whatever life throws my way.

Overall, my father's absence during my childhood had a significant impact on my days back then. It made me feel lonely, independent, resilient, and adaptable. However, it also taught me valuable life lessons that I still carry with me today.
summarised_answer: 1. Loneliness and isolation
2. Independence and self-reliance
3. Resilience and adaptability

question: 3. What lessons did you learn from the "272-steps lesson" that you applied throughout your life?

Firstly, I learned the importance of taking responsibility for my actions.

Secondly, I learned the importance of perseverance and determination.
The long and difficult journey up the mountain taught me that I could overcome any obstacle if I stayed focused and determined.
Finally, I learned the importance of humility and gratitude.
The experience taught me to be humble and grateful for the opportunities and resources that I have, and to appreciate the beauty of the world around me.
These lessons have helped me to become a more confident, resilient, and grateful person, and I will continue to apply them throughout my life..

3. Importance of humility and gratitude

Secondly, my father's approach has instilled in me a strong sense of perseverance and determination. When faced with a difficult problem, breaking it down into smaller parts allows me to focus on one step at a time, rather than becoming overwhelmed by the overall task. This approach has helped me to persist through challenges and setbacks, and to stay focused on the goal until it is achieved.

Finally, my father's approach has also taught me the value of collaboration and teamwork. This approach has been particularly useful in my personal life, where I have been able to work effectively with others to achieve common goals.

In conclusion, my father's approach to problem-solving has had a profound influence on my personal and professional life. It has taught me the importance of breaking down complex tasks into smaller, more manageable parts, and has instilled in me a strong sense of perseverance and determination. Additionally, it has emphasized the value of collaboration and teamwork, leading to more effective and comprehensive solutions.

2. This approach has instilled in me a strong sense of perseverance and determination, helping me to persist through challenges and setbacks.
3. My father's approach has emphasized the value of collaboration and teamwork, leading to more effective and comprehensive solutions.

definition: In this task, you're given a news article. Your job is to identify the umbrella topic of the article and write a set of 5 discussion questions pertaining the umbrella topic for opinion writing. You are not only provide the questions, in numbered bullet point form. You are not to provide anything aside from the questions in numbered bullet point form. You may assume that the writer has background experience on the umbrella topic. Good questions are expected to critically question the umbrella topic with reference to the article. Do not ask questions that can be answered correctly without understanding the paragraph. Each of your questions must be unique from the rest.
context: Frederick Lim
I never got to know my father well. He died suddenly when I was nine. He was only 44.

Although I didn’t have much time with him, I have fond memories of my boyhood days. And on Father’s Day every year, I look at his photograph, say a little prayer for him, and thank him for all that he gave me during our brief time together.

I grew up in Klang, a city in Selangor in Malaysia, where my father worked as a civil servant. After his death, my mother, older brother and I moved to Singapore where my uncle gave us a place to live. We lived modestly, with my father’s government pension and financial help from my uncle. There was no money for extras.

It was the absence of my father that marked my days back then. I missed how he doted on my brother and me, how he came home with presents and took us out to the movies. Most of all, I missed how he answered all our endless questions, which came easy for him as he had encyclopaedic knowledge.
What I remember most are the lessons he taught me that have guided me throughout my growing-up years and shaped my personality.
As a young boy, I took my father’s words as gospel truth and the advice he gave as gold, holding them close to my heart.
The biggest lesson has to be the “272-steps lesson”.

When I was around six years old, our family visited the Batu Caves Hindu temple near Kuala Lumpur. The mouth of Batu Caves was at the top of numerous and steep steps. When my father said there were 272 steps, I told him I would not make it all the way to the top.

His reply gave me the motivation to go for it: Getting to the top was just a matter of taking 16 steps to reach a landing, then another 16 steps to get to the next one, and if I kept going from one landing to another, I would reach the caves.
And so we climbed – my father holding my hand and both of us counting the steps out loud until we reached the caves.
The lesson learnt: Don’t be daunted by a big problem, as it can be tackled by breaking it down into smaller, more manageable parts.

I applied this lesson throughout my life – breaking a task into smaller steps, stages and sequences to eventually get it done. This approach to problem-solving has stood me in good stead in my personal and professional life.

When I was 45, I made a mid-career switch from stockbroking to journalism, joining CNA as a business reporter. As I knew little about TV production, I applied what my father taught me – do things in steps, stages and sequences. In time, with training and learning on the job, I became a senior editor of the station’s business programme.

Another lesson I learnt from my father was foundation-building. I remember as a child stacking building blocks, putting a square or round piece on top of another to see how high I could build the tower before the whole structure came crashing down.

My first few attempts collapsed in double-quick time. After seeing my failed attempts, my father showed me how I needed to build a strong foundation in order to get taller towers. I should not rush it, and take care to align the pieces to get a more stable structure.
I followed his advice, and my towers stood tall and did not collapse.

Building strong foundations became an integral part of everything I did in life. I was always well prepared before an examination, I trained hard before running a marathon, and I researched extensively before covering a news event.

My father also made sure he built a strong foundation in the education of his two sons. When we turned three, he introduced us to the alphabet, taught us numbers and read books to us to build up our vocabulary. He made us do simple sums and memorise the multiplication table.

On our family trips to other towns in Malaysia, my father would make us solve mental maths problems. To keep us occupied during the long drives, he asked us to work out how long it would take to get to the destination based on the speed of the car and the distance left to go.
There were also memory games, such as naming the capital cities of countries and the dates of historical events.

We went to the library regularly to borrow books, and he bought junior encyclopaedias to help us improve our general knowledge. He helped us with homework and reminded us to always go beyond what we learnt in school.
I grew up loving books and studied English literature in school. I developed a passion for writing and published two novels.

My father was a kind-hearted and generous man. He gave to charities readily and lent money to his cash-strapped colleagues. Our barber, who needed money for his family in India, borrowed from my father, who never asked for the loan to be repaid.
He talked to us about faith, and most importantly, showed us through his actions the importance of living life with honesty and integrity.

He told me never to take what was not mine at times when I found things. When I was a Scout in school, he reminded me during Job Week that I should do my best, as I was getting paid for the work. He told me he always gave his all, for the organisations he worked in and the people he worked with.

Of course, my father had his weaknesses. He loved food too much, often overate and rarely exercised. As he was only in his 40s when he died from typhoid fever, I have always wondered if he could have recovered from the bacterial infection if he had taken better care of his health.

My father could also be indecisive and lacked composure. I remember an incident when a beehive at the back of our house fell to the ground, and my father ran for cover from the swarm of bees. My mother’s quick thinking in setting the hive on fire saved the day.

Despite his shortcomings and his brief time with us, he had a lasting impact on our lives. I would like to think that he had a hand in the success story of my brother, who rose through the ranks to become a rear-admiral in the Singapore Navy and was Chief of Navy before he retired.

Although I do not have children of my own, I do have advice for all the fathers out there – teach your children well, as what you say will leave an indelible impression and stay with them for the rest of their lives. Just like how my father’s words and wise counsel have guided me through mine.
So this Father’s Day, I will gaze upon the photo of my dad, and thank him for making me who I am today.

Overall, my father's emphasis on foundation-building has been a critical influence in shaping who I am today and will continue to be an important guide in my future..

2. This has provided me with the skills and knowledge needed to pursue my career goals.
3. My father's emphasis on preparation has taught me the value of being proactive and taking responsibility for my own success.
4. This has allowed me to be better prepared for challenges and opportunities that come my way.
5. My father's emphasis on foundation-building has instilled in me a sense of discipline and determination.

definition: In this task, you're given a news article. Your job is to identify the umbrella topic of the article and write a set of 5 discussion questions pertaining the umbrella topic for opinion writing. You are not only provide the questions, in numbered bullet point form. You are not to provide anything aside from the questions in numbered bullet point form. You may assume that the writer has background experience on the umbrella topic. Good questions are expected to critically question the umbrella topic with reference to the article. Do not ask questions that can be answered correctly without understanding the paragraph. Each of your questions must be unique from the rest.
context: “Make sure to look your age.”
This was my friend’s blunt advice to me when I told her I was gearing up for a fellowship interview a few weeks ago.
Puzzled, I assured her that reporting assignments and previous internships had prepared me to dress formally and appropriately for the occasion.
“No, not just that. Be sure not to appear ‘too young’, perhaps put your hair up and avoid pinks or pastels,” she said, a suggestion I found somewhat amusing.

My friend, who like me is petite and around 1.5m tall, had recently been told during an interview for an overseas posting that she was too young for the job despite having the eight years of experience asked for in the advertisement.

While she could not know for certain why the company was not keen on her after the meeting, she felt it had to do with her appearance – that she was deemed unsuitable as she looked younger than her 30 years.

Her experience got me thinking about the way employers may judge a candidate’s eligibility for a job based on appearance. While looking well groomed and professional for an interview shows that the candidate is serious about the position, looking “too young” despite being competent is something beyond the control of millennials and Generation Z job seekers.

While ageism is commonly associated with discrimination against older workers, “reverse ageism” refers to the challenges of workers in their 20s and 30s who are hampered by age-specific stereotypes, such as being inexperienced and naive, that employers have of people of their age group.

Reverse ageism is not new, but it has been in focus lately among younger employees in post-pandemic times, as many bemoan the disruptions to their career development, finances and life plans over the past three years.
A study by the American Psychological Association in 2017 noted that younger employees actually experienced an equal or higher level of workplace discrimination than their older colleagues.

A survey by the National Trades Union Congress’ Employment and Employability Institute in 2019 looked at how millennials responded to stereotypes about their generation. While most agreed that millennials are prone to job-hopping and are tech-savvy, they disputed the stereotypes that they are selfish and unable to take hardship or instructions from a superior.

Some respondents said many millennials faced challenges that were different from and, in some cases, worse than those of the previous generation. These include degree inflation, a term referring to the declining value of degrees as more people have access to tertiary education; the constant need to recalibrate their skills to meet technological changes; and a longer trajectory to reach life milestones, like home or car ownership.

Ageism, like other forms of discrimination, is intersectional – meaning age intertwines with other aspects of a person’s identity, such as gender and economic status. Taken together, their disadvantages in the workforce increase.

A 2021 review on reverse ageism published on the American National Institutes of Health’s website noted that compared with their male peers, there was significant discrimination against younger women applying for highly skilled administrative jobs, reflecting the double whammy of both ageism and sexism in the workplace.
Many of these findings made me realise that the conventional idea of how to look and act at different ages of our lives no longer applied to people of my generation and the generations to come.

Add to this the fact that we are marrying and parenting later in life, and have different sets of responsibilities and priorities compared with previous generations, with many renting rather than owning housing, travelling significantly more than our predecessors, and pushing for more work-life balance.

The years of living with Covid-19 have also affected the way we look and behave. For instance, a 2021 study in medical journal The Lancet found that the prevalence of smoking among young people had decreased at the global level by approximately 33 per cent over the past 30 years.

There are fewer drinkers too. A report by the BBC in 2022 found that more young people were embracing being “sober curious” – drinking less and choosing to socialise while being sober – as a result of fewer opportunities to socialise or drink during the pandemic.
In terms of mental health, millennials, who were dubbed the “therapy generation” by a 2019 Wall Street Journal article, are seeking help more often than the previous generations.
Such lifestyle choices may continue to play an important part in how we age and the choices we make in the future.

In her widely shared May 2023 article in British Vogue titled “Why do so many millennials look and seem so much younger than they are?”, writer Daisy Jones looked at how millennials are ageing differently from their predecessors, partly because the norms surrounding age-specific lifestyles and clothing have changed.
Jones interpreted being called “younger” as not being taken seriously, despite her achievements and credentials.
I have seen these changing norms in women who are juggling motherhood and their careers in ways others may deem unconventional.

A relative in her mid-30s went on hiatus from full-time work after the birth of her first child a year ago and is considering a postgraduate degree while pregnant with her second child. In the meantime, she is doing remote project-based work that pays well.

Given the disruptions, employers must act and workplace culture must change to tackle both forms of ageism when it comes to hiring, career progression and flexible working arrangements, in order to avoid generational conflict between younger and older workers.

An article on job portal MyCareersFuture.sg noted that ageism at the workplace leads to a decrease in productivity and meritocracy, as the focus falls on workers’ age rather than their skills and talents.

One way to tackle reverse ageism is to provide more opportunities for older and younger employees to interact through mentoring and training programmes, to let them learn from and understand one another better.
Another option is for companies to consciously recruit and build intergenerational teams to capitalise on the strengths of different age groups.
Tapping young professionals’ guilds and groups, as well as networking opportunities, will also allow young people to bank on a support network of peers to help them navigate their career paths.

In future, safeguards against reverse ageism, which is often difficult to address, should also be reflected in national labour laws and company policies, such as moving away from looking at a candidate’s years of experience to the quality of the experience, and instituting diverse hiring panels that value the inputs of both junior and senior employees.

This will help foster greater inclusivity in the job market, so that workers with potential can focus more on the job than on how their appearance, lifestyle choices and personal views are perceived in the workplace.
question: 1. What is the main topic of the news article?
answer: The main topic of the news article is the rise of the renewable energy sector in Australia, particularly in the context of the shift towards a low-carbon economy.
The article highlights the significant increase in investment in renewable energy, the growth of renewable energy jobs, and the role of renewable energy in reducing carbon emissions..

2. Growth of renewable energy jobs.
3. Role of renewable energy in reducing carbon emissions.

context: “Make sure to look your age.”
This was my friend’s blunt advice to me when I told her I was gearing up for a fellowship interview a few weeks ago.
Puzzled, I assured her that reporting assignments and previous internships had prepared me to dress formally and appropriately for the occasion.
“No, not just that. Be sure not to appear ‘too young’, perhaps put your hair up and avoid pinks or pastels,” she said, a suggestion I found somewhat amusing.

My friend, who like me is petite and around 1.5m tall, had recently been told during an interview for an overseas posting that she was too young for the job despite having the eight years of experience asked for in the advertisement.

While she could not know for certain why the company was not keen on her after the meeting, she felt it had to do with her appearance – that she was deemed unsuitable as she looked younger than her 30 years.

Her experience got me thinking about the way employers may judge a candidate’s eligibility for a job based on appearance. While looking well groomed and professional for an interview shows that the candidate is serious about the position, looking “too young” despite being competent is something beyond the control of millennials and Generation Z job seekers.

While ageism is commonly associated with discrimination against older workers, “reverse ageism” refers to the challenges of workers in their 20s and 30s who are hampered by age-specific stereotypes, such as being inexperienced and naive, that employers have of people of their age group.

Reverse ageism is not new, but it has been in focus lately among younger employees in post-pandemic times, as many bemoan the disruptions to their career development, finances and life plans over the past three years.
A study by the American Psychological Association in 2017 noted that younger employees actually experienced an equal or higher level of workplace discrimination than their older colleagues.

A survey by the National Trades Union Congress’ Employment and Employability Institute in 2019 looked at how millennials responded to stereotypes about their generation. While most agreed that millennials are prone to job-hopping and are tech-savvy, they disputed the stereotypes that they are selfish and unable to take hardship or instructions from a superior.

Some respondents said many millennials faced challenges that were different from and, in some cases, worse than those of the previous generation. These include degree inflation, a term referring to the declining value of degrees as more people have access to tertiary education; the constant need to recalibrate their skills to meet technological changes; and a longer trajectory to reach life milestones, like home or car ownership.

Ageism, like other forms of discrimination, is intersectional – meaning age intertwines with other aspects of a person’s identity, such as gender and economic status. Taken together, their disadvantages in the workforce increase.

A 2021 review on reverse ageism published on the American National Institutes of Health’s website noted that compared with their male peers, there was significant discrimination against younger women applying for highly skilled administrative jobs, reflecting the double whammy of both ageism and sexism in the workplace.
Many of these findings made me realise that the conventional idea of how to look and act at different ages of our lives no longer applied to people of my generation and the generations to come.

Add to this the fact that we are marrying and parenting later in life, and have different sets of responsibilities and priorities compared with previous generations, with many renting rather than owning housing, travelling significantly more than our predecessors, and pushing for more work-life balance.

The years of living with Covid-19 have also affected the way we look and behave. For instance, a 2021 study in medical journal The Lancet found that the prevalence of smoking among young people had decreased at the global level by approximately 33 per cent over the past 30 years.

There are fewer drinkers too. A report by the BBC in 2022 found that more young people were embracing being “sober curious” – drinking less and choosing to socialise while being sober – as a result of fewer opportunities to socialise or drink during the pandemic.
In terms of mental health, millennials, who were dubbed the “therapy generation” by a 2019 Wall Street Journal article, are seeking help more often than the previous generations.
Such lifestyle choices may continue to play an important part in how we age and the choices we make in the future.

In her widely shared May 2023 article in British Vogue titled “Why do so many millennials look and seem so much younger than they are?”, writer Daisy Jones looked at how millennials are ageing differently from their predecessors, partly because the norms surrounding age-specific lifestyles and clothing have changed.
Jones interpreted being called “younger” as not being taken seriously, despite her achievements and credentials.
I have seen these changing norms in women who are juggling motherhood and their careers in ways others may deem unconventional.

A relative in her mid-30s went on hiatus from full-time work after the birth of her first child a year ago and is considering a postgraduate degree while pregnant with her second child. In the meantime, she is doing remote project-based work that pays well.

Given the disruptions, employers must act and workplace culture must change to tackle both forms of ageism when it comes to hiring, career progression and flexible working arrangements, in order to avoid generational conflict between younger and older workers.

An article on job portal MyCareersFuture.sg noted that ageism at the workplace leads to a decrease in productivity and meritocracy, as the focus falls on workers’ age rather than their skills and talents.

One way to tackle reverse ageism is to provide more opportunities for older and younger employees to interact through mentoring and training programmes, to let them learn from and understand one another better.
Another option is for companies to consciously recruit and build intergenerational teams to capitalise on the strengths of different age groups.
Tapping young professionals’ guilds and groups, as well as networking opportunities, will also allow young people to bank on a support network of peers to help them navigate their career paths.

In future, safeguards against reverse ageism, which is often difficult to address, should also be reflected in national labour laws and company policies, such as moving away from looking at a candidate’s years of experience to the quality of the experience, and instituting diverse hiring panels that value the inputs of both junior and senior employees.

This will help foster greater inclusivity in the job market, so that workers with potential can focus more on the job than on how their appearance, lifestyle choices and personal views are perceived in the workplace.
question: 4. What is ageism?
answer: Ageism is a form of discrimination or prejudice against individuals based on their age. It can manifest in various ways, including negative stereotypes, biased attitudes, and unequal treatment in the workplace or other settings. Ageism can affect individuals of all ages, including older adults who may face age-related discrimination, as well as younger individuals who may be subject to age-related stereotypes and biases.
Claim 1: Ageism is a prevalent form of discrimination in many societies.

Evidence: Ageism is a widespread issue that affects individuals of all ages. Research has shown that age discrimination is a significant problem in many countries, with many individuals reporting experiencing ageism in the workplace or other settings.
Claim 2: Ageism can have negative impacts on individuals' well-being and self-esteem.

Evidence: Ageism can have a negative impact on an individual's self-esteem and well-being. Research has shown that older adults who experience ageism may experience feelings of isolation, depression, and low self-esteem. Additionally, younger individuals who experience ageism may also experience negative impacts on their well-being and self-esteem.
Claim 3: Efforts should be made to address ageism in all its forms.

Evidence: Addressing ageism is essential to creating a more inclusive and equitable society for all ages. This can be achieved through education and awareness campaigns, anti-ageism policies and initiatives, and promoting age diversity and inclusivity in all settings. By addressing ageism, we can create a more positive and supportive environment for individuals of all ages.
summarised_answer: 1. Ageism is a prevalent form of discrimination in many societies.
2. Ageism can have negative impacts on individuals' well-being and self-esteem.
3. Efforts should be made to address ageism in all its forms.

3. Many younger employees face challenges that are different from and, in some cases, worse than those of the previous generation.
4. Ageism is intersectional and affects workers based on other aspects of their identity, such as gender and economic status.
5. The years of living with Covid-19 have affected the way younger people look and behave.

question: 6. How do younger employees respond to stereotypes about their generation?
answer: As a society, we are becoming increasingly aware of the impact of stereotypes on individuals and groups, and younger employees are no exception. Research has shown that stereotypes about younger generations can be particularly harmful, as they can limit opportunities and perpetuate negative stereotypes.

One response to these stereotypes is for younger employees to reject them and work to challenge them. This can involve actively seeking out opportunities to prove themselves and demonstrating their abilities in the workplace. Younger employees may also seek out mentors or role models who can help them to overcome stereotypes and break down barriers.

Another response is for younger employees to embrace their stereotypes and use them to their advantage. This can involve using the energy and enthusiasm associated with youth to drive innovation and creativity in the workplace. Some younger employees may also use stereotypes to create a sense of community and solidarity among their peers.

Overall, it is important for employers to recognize that stereotypes about younger generations can be harmful and to work to create a workplace culture that values diversity and inclusivity. This can involve actively seeking out diverse perspectives and experiences, providing opportunities for mentorship and professional development, and actively working to combat stereotypes and biases. By doing so, employers can create a workplace that is more productive, innovative, and inclusive for all employees.

2. Younger employees can challenge stereotypes by actively seeking out opportunities and demonstrating their abilities in the workplace.
3. Younger employees can embrace their stereotypes and use them to their advantage by using their energy and enthusiasm to drive innovation and creativity.
4. Employers should recognize the harm of stereotypes about younger generations and work to create a workplace culture that values diversity and inclusivity.
5. This can involve actively seeking out diverse perspectives, providing opportunities for mentorship and professional development, and actively working to combat stereotypes and biases.

question: 7. What is degree inflation?
answer: Degree Inflation is a phenomenon that has emerged in higher education where the number of degrees awarded has increased significantly over the years, often without a corresponding increase in the level of knowledge or skills of the graduates. This has led to concerns that many degrees are being watered down, and that the value of a degree is being diminished.
Claim 1: Degree inflation has led to a decrease in the quality of education in higher institutions.

One of the main criticisms of degree inflation is that it has led to a decrease in the quality of education in higher institutions. This is because the number of degrees being awarded has increased so rapidly that institutions have had to lower their standards in order to keep up with the demand. This has resulted in students being awarded degrees without having the necessary knowledge or skills to demonstrate their competence in a particular field.
Claim 2: The over-production of degrees has led to a surplus of graduates in the job market.

Another concern is that the over-production of degrees has led to a surplus of graduates in the job market. This has made it difficult for recent graduates to find employment, as there are simply too many people competing for too few jobs. This has led to a decrease in the value of a degree, as employers are no longer able to rely on a degree as a guarantee of a person's competence.
Claim 3: The increase in the number of degrees awarded has also led to an increase in student debt.

Finally, the increase in the number of degrees being awarded has also led to an increase in student debt. Many students are taking on significant amounts of debt in order to pay for their education, and they are often left with significant amounts of debt even after graduating. This has led to concerns that students are being priced out of higher education, and that the cost of a degree is becoming unaffordable.

In conclusion, degree inflation is a serious issue in higher education that has led to a decrease in the quality of education, a surplus of graduates in the job market, and an increase in student debt. These issues have significant implications for both students and employers, and they highlight the need for institutions to re-evaluate their policies and practices in order to ensure that degrees remain a valuable and meaningful indicator of competence and achievement.
summarised_answer: 1. Degree inflation has led to a decrease in the quality of education in higher institutions.
2. The over-production of degrees has led to a surplus of graduates in the job market.
3. The increase in the number of degrees awarded has also led to an increase in student debt.

2. Reverse ageism refers to discrimination against workers in their 20s and 30s based on age-specific stereotypes.

definition: In this task, you're given a news article. Your job is to identify the umbrella topic of the article and write a set of 5 discussion questions pertaining the umbrella topic for opinion writing. You are not only provide the questions, in numbered bullet point form. You are not to provide anything aside from the questions in numbered bullet point form. You may assume that the writer has background experience on the umbrella topic. Good questions are expected to critically question the umbrella topic with reference to the article. Do not ask questions that can be answered correctly without understanding the paragraph. Each of your questions must be unique from the rest.
context: “Make sure to look your age.”
This was my friend’s blunt advice to me when I told her I was gearing up for a fellowship interview a few weeks ago.
Puzzled, I assured her that reporting assignments and previous internships had prepared me to dress formally and appropriately for the occasion.
“No, not just that. Be sure not to appear ‘too young’, perhaps put your hair up and avoid pinks or pastels,” she said, a suggestion I found somewhat amusing.

My friend, who like me is petite and around 1.5m tall, had recently been told during an interview for an overseas posting that she was too young for the job despite having the eight years of experience asked for in the advertisement.

While she could not know for certain why the company was not keen on her after the meeting, she felt it had to do with her appearance – that she was deemed unsuitable as she looked younger than her 30 years.

Her experience got me thinking about the way employers may judge a candidate’s eligibility for a job based on appearance. While looking well groomed and professional for an interview shows that the candidate is serious about the position, looking “too young” despite being competent is something beyond the control of millennials and Generation Z job seekers.

While ageism is commonly associated with discrimination against older workers, “reverse ageism” refers to the challenges of workers in their 20s and 30s who are hampered by age-specific stereotypes, such as being inexperienced and naive, that employers have of people of their age group.

Reverse ageism is not new, but it has been in focus lately among younger employees in post-pandemic times, as many bemoan the disruptions to their career development, finances and life plans over the past three years.
A study by the American Psychological Association in 2017 noted that younger employees actually experienced an equal or higher level of workplace discrimination than their older colleagues.

A survey by the National Trades Union Congress’ Employment and Employability Institute in 2019 looked at how millennials responded to stereotypes about their generation. While most agreed that millennials are prone to job-hopping and are tech-savvy, they disputed the stereotypes that they are selfish and unable to take hardship or instructions from a superior.

Some respondents said many millennials faced challenges that were different from and, in some cases, worse than those of the previous generation. These include degree inflation, a term referring to the declining value of degrees as more people have access to tertiary education; the constant need to recalibrate their skills to meet technological changes; and a longer trajectory to reach life milestones, like home or car ownership.

Ageism, like other forms of discrimination, is intersectional – meaning age intertwines with other aspects of a person’s identity, such as gender and economic status. Taken together, their disadvantages in the workforce increase.

A 2021 review on reverse ageism published on the American National Institutes of Health’s website noted that compared with their male peers, there was significant discrimination against younger women applying for highly skilled administrative jobs, reflecting the double whammy of both ageism and sexism in the workplace.
Many of these findings made me realise that the conventional idea of how to look and act at different ages of our lives no longer applied to people of my generation and the generations to come.

Add to this the fact that we are marrying and parenting later in life, and have different sets of responsibilities and priorities compared with previous generations, with many renting rather than owning housing, travelling significantly more than our predecessors, and pushing for more work-life balance.

The years of living with Covid-19 have also affected the way we look and behave. For instance, a 2021 study in medical journal The Lancet found that the prevalence of smoking among young people had decreased at the global level by approximately 33 per cent over the past 30 years.

There are fewer drinkers too. A report by the BBC in 2022 found that more young people were embracing being “sober curious” – drinking less and choosing to socialise while being sober – as a result of fewer opportunities to socialise or drink during the pandemic.
In terms of mental health, millennials, who were dubbed the “therapy generation” by a 2019 Wall Street Journal article, are seeking help more often than the previous generations.
Such lifestyle choices may continue to play an important part in how we age and the choices we make in the future.

In her widely shared May 2023 article in British Vogue titled “Why do so many millennials look and seem so much younger than they are?”, writer Daisy Jones looked at how millennials are ageing differently from their predecessors, partly because the norms surrounding age-specific lifestyles and clothing have changed.
Jones interpreted being called “younger” as not being taken seriously, despite her achievements and credentials.
I have seen these changing norms in women who are juggling motherhood and their careers in ways others may deem unconventional.

A relative in her mid-30s went on hiatus from full-time work after the birth of her first child a year ago and is considering a postgraduate degree while pregnant with her second child. In the meantime, she is doing remote project-based work that pays well.

Given the disruptions, employers must act and workplace culture must change to tackle both forms of ageism when it comes to hiring, career progression and flexible working arrangements, in order to avoid generational conflict between younger and older workers.

An article on job portal MyCareersFuture.sg noted that ageism at the workplace leads to a decrease in productivity and meritocracy, as the focus falls on workers’ age rather than their skills and talents.

One way to tackle reverse ageism is to provide more opportunities for older and younger employees to interact through mentoring and training programmes, to let them learn from and understand one another better.
Another option is for companies to consciously recruit and build intergenerational teams to capitalise on the strengths of different age groups.
Tapping young professionals’ guilds and groups, as well as networking opportunities, will also allow young people to bank on a support network of peers to help them navigate their career paths.

In future, safeguards against reverse ageism, which is often difficult to address, should also be reflected in national labour laws and company policies, such as moving away from looking at a candidate’s years of experience to the quality of the experience, and instituting diverse hiring panels that value the inputs of both junior and senior employees.

This will help foster greater inclusivity in the job market, so that workers with potential can focus more on the job than on how their appearance, lifestyle choices and personal views are perceived in the workplace.
question: 8. How does the conventional idea of age apply to people of the writer's generation and future generations?
answer: The conventional idea of age is a social construct that has been shaped by cultural, historical, and societal factors. In the past, age was often used as a marker of maturity, experience, and wisdom. However, with the rapid pace of technological change and shifting cultural norms, the conventional idea of age is becoming increasingly irrelevant.

For people of the writer's generation, the conventional idea of age may still hold some weight, as many were raised in a time when age was a more significant factor in society. However, as people are living longer and staying healthier, age is becoming less of a determinant of physical and mental abilities. In the future, this shift in perception of age is likely to continue, with age becoming less of a factor in determining a person's potential and capabilities.

Furthermore, as society becomes more diverse and inclusive, the conventional idea of age is likely to be challenged even more. Age is often used as a proxy for experience and wisdom, but this assumption may not be accurate for all individuals. In the future, it is likely that the conventional idea of age will be redefined to better reflect the diversity of society, with age being seen as just one aspect of a person's identity.

In conclusion, the conventional idea of age is becoming increasingly irrelevant, and is likely to continue to change in the future as society evolves. The idea of age as a determinant of potential and capabilities is likely to become less significant, and will be replaced by a more nuanced understanding of age as just one aspect of a person's identity.

2. Age was often used as a marker of maturity, experience, and wisdom in the past.
3. The conventional idea of age is becoming increasingly irrelevant due to rapid pace of technological change and shifting cultural norms.
4. Age is becoming less of a determinant of physical and mental abilities as people are living longer and staying healthier.

7. The conventional idea of age is likely to be challenged even more in the future as society becomes more diverse and inclusive.
8. Age is often used as a proxy for experience and wisdom, but this assumption may not be accurate for all individuals.

question: 9. How has living with Covid-19 affected the way people look and behave?
answer: Living with Covid-19 has had a significant impact on the way people look and behave. Here are three key claims that support this statement:

1. Clothing choices have changed: With the widespread adoption of masks and face coverings, people have had to adapt their clothing choices to accommodate these items. Many individuals now wear masks in public places, and those who do not wear masks may still choose to wear face coverings to avoid contact with others. This has led to an increase in the popularity of clothing and accessories that can be worn over masks, such as hoods and scarves.

2. Social behavior has been altered: The social distancing measures put in place during the pandemic have had a significant impact on social behavior. People have had to become more cautious and reserved in their interactions with others, avoiding physical contact and limiting the number of people they come into contact with. This has led to a decrease in the frequency and intensity of social interactions, as well as a shift towards online communication.

3. Mental health has been affected: The prolonged nature of the pandemic has had a significant impact on mental health, with many people experiencing anxiety, depression, and other mental health issues. The constant fear of contracting the virus and the uncertainty of the future has taken a toll on individuals, leading to changes in behavior and an increased reliance on self-care and isolation.
summarised_answer: 1. Clothing choices have changed due to the widespread adoption of masks and face coverings.
2. Social behavior has been altered due to the implementation of social distancing measures.
3. Mental health has been affected due to the prolonged nature of the pandemic.

question: 10. What are
answer: 10. What are the main arguments for and against the use of nuclear energy?

Claim: The use of nuclear energy has several advantages, such as providing a large amount of electricity, reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and providing energy security. However, there are also several disadvantages to nuclear energy, such as the high upfront costs, the risk of accidents, and the issue of nuclear waste.

Evidence: Nuclear energy is a reliable source of electricity, and it can provide a large amount of power without producing greenhouse gas emissions. Nuclear power plants can operate continuously, and they do not produce emissions during operation. This means that they can provide a steady stream of electricity, which is particularly useful for large industrial and commercial users. In addition, the cost of nuclear energy is relatively low compared to other forms of electricity generation, such as solar or wind power. However, there are also several disadvantages to nuclear energy. The construction of a nuclear power plant is expensive, and the cost of building a new plant can be several billion dollars. In addition, there is a risk of accidents at nuclear power plants, which can lead to environmental damage and public health concerns. Finally, the disposal of nuclear waste is a major issue, as it can be highly radioactive and pose a risk to public health and the environment for thousands of years.
summarised_answer: 1. Advantages of nuclear energy:
* Provides a large amount of electricity
* Reduces greenhouse gas emissions
* Provides energy security
2. Disadvantages of nuclear energy:
* High upfront costs
* Risk of accidents
* Nuclear waste disposal issue

context: Wee Jin Sin
The horse racing fraternity has reacted with dismay to the Government’s recent decision to close the Singapore Turf Club (STC) in Kranji.
This will mean the end of the 180-year-old sport in Singapore and the loss of hundreds of jobs. It also leaves horse owners, jockeys and the horses themselves facing an uncertain future.
Despite the sympathy for STC’s employees, the 120ha of land freed up by the club’s closure opens up many possibilities for other urgent land use requirements.
Put simply, one key aim of land use planning is to use any given piece of land to bring the most benefits to the most people.
With local horse racing experiencing declining spectatorship over the years, it makes sense to redevelop the land on which the STC sits to meet urgent housing demand, especially for public housing.

The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has indicated that planning for the site will take two or three years. Beyond the housing, leisure and recreation uses already announced, it is too early to speculate what else might come up on the land.
However, there are hints about how government agencies plan to approach the site.
A spokesman for the URA has noted that Singapore’s northern region as a whole is very “green” and that the authority would take the surrounding context into account.

The surrounding physical context includes the Mandai Mangrove and Mudflat Nature Park to the north, and the Kranji Reservoir, Kranji Coastal Nature Park and Kranji Marshes to the north-east and east. The Rail Corridor is also just north of the STC site.
Beyond physical factors, general attitudes towards greenery have evolved over the years.

Indeed, it was reported earlier in June in The Straits Times that a study by the National University of Singapore (NUS) Centre for Nature-based Climate Solutions quantified what I had long noticed among my own friends and acquaintances – that Singaporeans value views of greenery enough to pay a premium for them.
This means we have moved beyond equating greenery only with formal parks or nature areas.

The Rail Corridor, for example, is a green leisure and recreation space for daytime joggers and walkers, but also doubles as a route for cyclists going to work, and a linkway for wildlife connectivity at night.

The Clementi Nature Corridor announced by the National Parks Board in July 2021 as an ecological connection between Bukit Timah Nature Reserve and the Southern Ridges, and the 400ha Sungei Buloh Nature Park Network, are emblematic of the Government’s current science-based approach to managing the balance between nature conservation and development needs.

In that regard, beyond parks and landscaped greenery, there could be an opportunity for incorporating nature corridors in any new town at the STC site to improve the ecological links between existing nature areas around Kranji.

The recent NUS study also noted that the area of greenery per person within residential towns declined from 17.7 sq m to 13.7 sq m from 2008 to 2020. Given the premium we place on it, I believe most Singaporeans would welcome it if we could add to the amount of greenery in Singapore.
According to news reports, URA has not ruled out the possibility of retaining some STC structures if it makes sense to keep or repurpose them for other uses.

Adaptive re-use of existing buildings was in the news recently when The Business Times reported London-based environmental engineer Patrick Bellew and Singapore building experts arguing that in terms of embodied carbon, it is not environmentally sustainable to demolish buildings and rebuild them.

Embodied carbon refers to the greenhouse gases that are released when building materials are made, transported and assembled. According to Mr Bellew, even for “super green” buildings, embodied carbon constitutes about 80 per cent of the carbon emissions in the first 50 years of a building’s lifespan.
In other words, no matter how environmentally sustainable a building is when operational, a lot of its carbon emissions had already been expended during its construction and early years.
Adaptive re-use of existing buildings would help negate the excessive carbon emissions inherent in the demolish-and-rebuild model.
With the STC now about 25 years old, its buildings are good candidates for adaptive re-use as they are unlikely to be near the end of their structural lifespan.
In fact, there are precedents overseas of sporting stadiums being repurposed for housing and other uses.
One example is the old Highbury stadium, the home of Arsenal Football Club for 93 years until 2006. The stadium was converted into apartments for the new Highbury Square development.
In the American city of Indianapolis, the 80-year-old grandstand of the historic Bush baseball stadium was converted into an apartment complex known as Stadium Lofts, which opened in 2013.
This, of course, does not necessarily mean that a different building, like STC’s grandstand, can be similarly repurposed.

Would retaining the grandstand unacceptably constrain the development potential and spatial planning of the rest of the site? Is the building suitable to be repurposed for the uses being considered, and would the effort be prohibitively expensive or too time-consuming to be practical?
These are tough questions and hard economics, and pragmatism may render adaptive re-use of the grandstand unfeasible.
However, there is value in considering the preservation of the intangible social memory of horse racing’s long history in Singapore once it is gone, and honouring those who were part of it.

If there is scope for adaptive re-use of the grandstand, one can imagine a day in the not-too-distant future when former STC employees or horse trainers could visit the lush and green new town and point out the repurposed grandstand to their children.
Even with their illustrious sport gone, the building would be a meaningful legacy of Singapore’s horse racing heritage, and the glory days of the Kranji racetrack.

question: 2. How will the closure of the Singapore Turf Club affect the horse racing fraternity?
answer: The closure of the Singapore Turf Club will have a significant impact on the horse racing fraternity. The club has been a central hub for horse racing enthusiasts and has played a vital role in promoting the sport in Singapore. The closure will result in the loss of jobs for the employees who work at the club, and it will also have a negative impact on the local economy.

One of the most significant impacts of the closure will be on the employees who work at the Singapore Turf Club. The loss of these jobs will have a negative impact on the local community, as many people will be left without employment.

In addition to the impact on the local community, the closure of the Singapore Turf Club will also have a negative impact on the local economy. The club generates a significant amount of revenue for the local area, and the loss of this revenue will be felt by local businesses. The closure will also have a negative impact on the tourism industry, as the club attracts visitors from around the world who come to watch horse racing.
Overall, the closure of the Singapore Turf Club will have a significant impact on the horse racing fraternity, including the loss of jobs, negative impact on the local community and economy.

definition: In this task, you're given a news article. Your job is to identify the umbrella topic of the article and write a set of 5 discussion questions pertaining the umbrella topic for opinion writing. You are not only provide the questions, in numbered bullet point form. You are not to provide anything aside from the questions in numbered bullet point form. You may assume that the writer has background experience on the umbrella topic. Good questions are expected to critically question the umbrella topic with reference to the article. Do not ask questions that can be answered correctly without understanding the paragraph. Each of your questions must be unique from the rest.
context: Wee Jin Sin
The horse racing fraternity has reacted with dismay to the Government’s recent decision to close the Singapore Turf Club (STC) in Kranji.
This will mean the end of the 180-year-old sport in Singapore and the loss of hundreds of jobs. It also leaves horse owners, jockeys and the horses themselves facing an uncertain future.
Despite the sympathy for STC’s employees, the 120ha of land freed up by the club’s closure opens up many possibilities for other urgent land use requirements.
Put simply, one key aim of land use planning is to use any given piece of land to bring the most benefits to the most people.
With local horse racing experiencing declining spectatorship over the years, it makes sense to redevelop the land on which the STC sits to meet urgent housing demand, especially for public housing.

The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has indicated that planning for the site will take two or three years. Beyond the housing, leisure and recreation uses already announced, it is too early to speculate what else might come up on the land.
However, there are hints about how government agencies plan to approach the site.
A spokesman for the URA has noted that Singapore’s northern region as a whole is very “green” and that the authority would take the surrounding context into account.

The surrounding physical context includes the Mandai Mangrove and Mudflat Nature Park to the north, and the Kranji Reservoir, Kranji Coastal Nature Park and Kranji Marshes to the north-east and east. The Rail Corridor is also just north of the STC site.
Beyond physical factors, general attitudes towards greenery have evolved over the years.

Indeed, it was reported earlier in June in The Straits Times that a study by the National University of Singapore (NUS) Centre for Nature-based Climate Solutions quantified what I had long noticed among my own friends and acquaintances – that Singaporeans value views of greenery enough to pay a premium for them.
This means we have moved beyond equating greenery only with formal parks or nature areas.

The Rail Corridor, for example, is a green leisure and recreation space for daytime joggers and walkers, but also doubles as a route for cyclists going to work, and a linkway for wildlife connectivity at night.

The Clementi Nature Corridor announced by the National Parks Board in July 2021 as an ecological connection between Bukit Timah Nature Reserve and the Southern Ridges, and the 400ha Sungei Buloh Nature Park Network, are emblematic of the Government’s current science-based approach to managing the balance between nature conservation and development needs.

In that regard, beyond parks and landscaped greenery, there could be an opportunity for incorporating nature corridors in any new town at the STC site to improve the ecological links between existing nature areas around Kranji.

The recent NUS study also noted that the area of greenery per person within residential towns declined from 17.7 sq m to 13.7 sq m from 2008 to 2020. Given the premium we place on it, I believe most Singaporeans would welcome it if we could add to the amount of greenery in Singapore.
According to news reports, URA has not ruled out the possibility of retaining some STC structures if it makes sense to keep or repurpose them for other uses.

Adaptive re-use of existing buildings was in the news recently when The Business Times reported London-based environmental engineer Patrick Bellew and Singapore building experts arguing that in terms of embodied carbon, it is not environmentally sustainable to demolish buildings and rebuild them.

Embodied carbon refers to the greenhouse gases that are released when building materials are made, transported and assembled. According to Mr Bellew, even for “super green” buildings, embodied carbon constitutes about 80 per cent of the carbon emissions in the first 50 years of a building’s lifespan.
In other words, no matter how environmentally sustainable a building is when operational, a lot of its carbon emissions had already been expended during its construction and early years.
Adaptive re-use of existing buildings would help negate the excessive carbon emissions inherent in the demolish-and-rebuild model.
With the STC now about 25 years old, its buildings are good candidates for adaptive re-use as they are unlikely to be near the end of their structural lifespan.
In fact, there are precedents overseas of sporting stadiums being repurposed for housing and other uses.
One example is the old Highbury stadium, the home of Arsenal Football Club for 93 years until 2006. The stadium was converted into apartments for the new Highbury Square development.
In the American city of Indianapolis, the 80-year-old grandstand of the historic Bush baseball stadium was converted into an apartment complex known as Stadium Lofts, which opened in 2013.
This, of course, does not necessarily mean that a different building, like STC’s grandstand, can be similarly repurposed.

Would retaining the grandstand unacceptably constrain the development potential and spatial planning of the rest of the site? Is the building suitable to be repurposed for the uses being considered, and would the effort be prohibitively expensive or too time-consuming to be practical?
These are tough questions and hard economics, and pragmatism may render adaptive re-use of the grandstand unfeasible.
However, there is value in considering the preservation of the intangible social memory of horse racing’s long history in Singapore once it is gone, and honouring those who were part of it.

If there is scope for adaptive re-use of the grandstand, one can imagine a day in the not-too-distant future when former STC employees or horse trainers could visit the lush and green new town and point out the repurposed grandstand to their children.
Even with their illustrious sport gone, the building would be a meaningful legacy of Singapore’s horse racing heritage, and the glory days of the Kranji racetrack.

• Wee Jin Sin was an urban planner at the Urban Redevelopment Authority and an airport planner at the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore. He is now pursuing a graduate diploma in counselling psychology.
question: 3. What are some potential benefits of redeveloping the land on which the STC sits?
answer: Redeveloping the land on which the STC sits can bring several potential benefits to the community.

Additionally, the redevelopment can also increase the tax base for the city, which can be used to fund public services and infrastructure projects.
Furthermore, the redevelopment can also lead to an increase in property values in the surrounding area, which can benefit both homeowners and businesses.
However, it is important to consider the potential impacts on the community and the environment before making any decisions about redevelopment..

2. Increase in tax base for the city.
3. Increase in property values in the surrounding area.
4. Potential impacts on the community and the environment.

question: 4. How might the surrounding context of the STC site be taken into account by government agencies?
answer: In order to effectively consider the surrounding context of the STC site, government agencies must take into account the following factors:

1. Environmental Impact: The government must consider the environmental impact of the site on the surrounding area. This includes potential air and water pollution, noise, and the impact on local wildlife.

2. Land Use: The government must consider the existing land use in the surrounding area and how it might be affected by the STC site. This includes the potential impact on nearby residential and commercial areas, as well as any potential for conflict with existing land uses.

3. Transportation: The government must consider the potential impact of the STC site on transportation in the surrounding area. This includes the potential for increased traffic, as well as the impact on public transportation and local road networks.
By taking these factors into account, government agencies can ensure that the STC site is developed in a way that is sustainable and minimizes negative impacts on the surrounding area.

question: 5. What role do green spaces play in the development of Singapore?
answer: Green spaces play a crucial role in the development of Singapore. They provide a range of benefits that contribute to the quality of life of its residents, promote environmental sustainability, and support economic growth.

Firstly, green spaces provide opportunities for physical activity and recreation. They offer a range of recreational facilities such as parks, playgrounds, and sports facilities, which provide opportunities for residents to engage in physical activities. This helps to promote healthy lifestyles and improve the mental and physical well-being of Singaporeans.

Secondly, green spaces provide opportunities for environmental education and conservation. They offer a range of educational programs and activities that promote environmental awareness and encourage the conservation of natural resources. This helps to create a sense of environmental responsibility among Singaporeans and promotes sustainable development.

Finally, green spaces provide opportunities for economic growth. They attract businesses and investors who recognize the importance of a healthy and sustainable environment. This helps to create jobs and promote economic growth, while also supporting the preservation of green spaces for future generations.

In conclusion, green spaces play a vital role in the development of Singapore. They provide opportunities for physical activity and recreation, promote environmental awareness and conservation, and support economic growth. It is essential that the government continues to invest in the preservation and development of green spaces to ensure that Singapore remains a healthy, sustainable, and livable city.
summarised_answer: 1. Green spaces provide opportunities for physical activity and recreation.
2. Green spaces provide opportunities for environmental education and conservation.
3. Green spaces provide opportunities for economic growth.
4. Green spaces are essential for the development of Singapore.
5. The government should invest in the preservation and development of green spaces to promote healthy, sustainable, and livable city.

This, of course, does not necessarily mean that a different building, like STC’s grandstand, can be similarly repurposed.

Would retaining the grandstand unacceptably constrain the development potential and spatial planning of the rest of the site? Is the building suitable to be repurposed for the uses being considered, and would the effort be prohibitively expensive or too time-consuming to be practical?
These are tough questions and hard economics, and pragmatism may render adaptive re-use of the grandstand unfeasible.
However, there is value in considering the preservation of the intangible social memory of horse racing’s long history in Singapore once it is gone, and honouring those who were part of it.

If there is scope for adaptive re-use of the grandstand, one can imagine a day in the not-too-distant future when former STC employees or horse trainers could visit the lush and green new town and point out the repurposed grandstand to their children.
Even with their illustrious sport gone, the building would be a meaningful legacy of Singapore’s horse racing heritage, and the glory days of the Kranji racetrack.

• Wee Jin Sin was an urban planner at the Urban Redevelopment Authority and an airport planner at the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore. He is now pursuing a graduate diploma in counselling psychology.
question: 6. How might the closure of the STC impact the ecological connections between nature areas around Kranji?
answer: The closure of the STC could have a significant impact on the ecological connections between nature areas around Kranji. The STC serves as a critical wildlife corridor that connects several nature areas in the region, including the Kranji Marshes, the Kranji Nature Reserve, and the Sungei Buloh Wetland Reserve. The STC also provides a vital link between the various habitats found within these nature areas, including mangrove forests, wetlands, and freshwater and brackish water bodies.

Without the STC, the wildlife that rely on this corridor for movement and habitat connectivity would be severely impacted. For example, the migratory birds that use the STC as a flyway would be unable to navigate between their breeding and nesting grounds in the north and their wintering grounds in the south. Similarly, the freshwater and brackish water fish that rely on the STC for migration and spawning would be impacted by the closure.

Furthermore, the closure of the STC could also impact the ecological processes that take place within the surrounding nature areas. For example, the STC helps to regulate water levels within the wetlands and mangrove forests, which can impact the growth and survival of various plant and animal species.

In conclusion, the closure of the STC would have a significant impact on the ecological connections between nature areas around Kranji, and would likely result in negative consequences for the wildlife and ecological processes within these areas. It is therefore important to explore alternative solutions to preserve the STC and maintain the ecological connections between nature areas in the region.
summarised_answer: 1. The STC serves as a critical wildlife corridor connecting several nature areas in the region.
2. The STC provides a vital link between various habitats found within these nature areas.
3. The closure of the STC would impact the movement and habitat connectivity of wildlife, including migratory birds and freshwater and brackish water fish.
4. The closure of the STC could also impact ecological processes within the surrounding nature areas.
5. The preservation of the STC is important to maintain ecological connections between nature areas in the region and prevent negative consequences for wildlife and ecological processes.
